[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: allows_transaction()] [Filter bypass] Can an attacker exploit the first-match-wins rule ordering to bypass deny rules by crafting transactions that match allow rules earlier in the list, potentially allowing unauthorized transactions to bypass security filters? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: allows_transaction()] [Default allow vulnerability] Does the default allow behavior when no rules match create a security risk where incomplete filter configurations allow all transactions, potentially bypassing critical access controls? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: allows_transaction()] [Empty filter bypass] Can an attacker exploit the empty filter check that returns true to bypass all filtering by forcing or manipulating the filter into an empty state? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: allows_transaction()] [Rule precedence manipulation] If multiple rules could match a transaction, can an attacker predict and exploit the rule ordering to ensure a favorable outcome, bypassing intended deny rules? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: filter_transactions()] [Batch processing bypass] Can an attacker exploit the batch filtering logic to cause inconsistent filtering results across a set of transactions, potentially allowing some malicious transactions through while legitimate ones are blocked? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: add_multiple_matchers_filter()] [Rule injection] Can an attacker manipulate the rule addition process to inject malicious allow rules that override existing deny rules through the mutable self modification pattern? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches() - TransactionMatcher::TransactionId] [Hash collision] Can an attacker craft a malicious transaction that produces the same committed_hash() as a whitelisted transaction ID, allowing unauthorized transactions to bypass ID-based filters through hash collisions? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches() - TransactionMatcher::TransactionId] [Transaction replay] Does the TransactionId matcher properly prevent replay attacks, or can an attacker reuse a previously allowed transaction hash to bypass filters after the transaction was executed? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches() - TransactionMatcher::TransactionId] [Hash preimage attack] Can an attacker pre-compute transaction hashes to find allowable transaction IDs before submitting transactions, bypassing ID-based access controls? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_sender_address()] [Sender spoofing] Can an attacker bypass sender-based filters by manipulating the transaction sender field before signature verification, potentially impersonating authorized senders? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_sender_address()] [Account rotation bypass] If an account undergoes authentication key rotation, can transactions from the old key bypass sender filters that were configured for the rotated address? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches() - TransactionMatcher::Sender] [Null address bypass] Can an attacker use special addresses like 0x0 or system addresses to bypass sender-based filtering rules? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_entry_function_module_address()] [Payload type confusion] Can an attacker bypass module address filters by switching between different payload types (Script, EntryFunction, Multisig, EncryptedPayload) that may have inconsistent address extraction logic? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_entry_function_module_address()] [ModuleBundle bypass] Does the function return false for ModuleBundle payloads, allowing module deployment transactions to bypass module address filters entirely? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_entry_function_module_address()] [EncryptedPayload decryption failure] Can an attacker craft malformed encrypted payloads where executable_ref() fails, causing the filter to return false and allow the transaction through by default? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_entry_function_module_address()] [Empty executable bypass] Does the TransactionExecutableRef::Empty case correctly handle empty payloads, or can attackers use empty executables to bypass module address filtering? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: compare_entry_function_module_address()] [Module address spoofing] Can an attacker craft entry functions that appear to call one module address but actually call another through reflection or indirection? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_entry_function()] [Function name case sensitivity] Are function and module name comparisons case-sensitive, allowing attackers to bypass filters by using different casing (e.g., 'Transfer' vs 'transfer')? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: compare_entry_function()] [String normalization bypass] Can an attacker bypass entry function filters using Unicode normalization tricks, whitespace manipulation, or similar string encoding issues? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_entry_function()] [Multisig unwrap vulnerability] Does the unwrap_or(false) on multisig transaction_payload create a bypass where None payloads are allowed through filters? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_entry_function()] [EncryptedPayload error handling] If payload.executable_ref() returns an error, the function returns false (no match), potentially allowing malformed encrypted transactions to bypass deny rules - can this be exploited? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: compare_entry_function()] [Module name length limit] Are there any length limits on module_name and function_name strings that could cause truncation or comparison failures? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_entry_function()] [Script payload bypass] Does returning false for Script payloads mean all script transactions bypass entry function filters, potentially allowing arbitrary code execution? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches() - TransactionMatcher::AccountAddress] [OR logic bypass] Can an attacker exploit the OR logic across five different address checks to bypass filters by embedding the target address in an unexpected location that wasn't intended to trigger the filter? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches() - TransactionMatcher::AccountAddress] [Secondary address bypass] Can attackers bypass account address filters by using the address as a secondary signer or fee payer rather than the primary sender? (Medium)
